newsitem.title: BELGIUM: European Union gene policy in disarray.
newsitem.headline: European Union gene policy in disarray.

text.p: The European Commission has gone back to the drawing board to clarify policy on gene-modified foods such as corn and soybeans, an official said Friday.

A meeting of senior officials Thursday rejected a draft text meant to bring coherence to Commission policy across a range of areas, including approval for genetically modified organisms and rules for genetically modified human food, animal feed and plant seeds.
The official said a second paper would be prepared for discussion by Commissioners on June 11, but there probably would be no rapid solution to the issue.
"I would not put too much emphasis on the (June) timetable," he said.
The draft proposal governing use of genetically modified foods in animal feed had suggested labelling rules for all feeds containing gene-altered varieties.

But the proposal said mandatory labels implied a requirement to segregate genetically modified varieties from other strains in shipments, an idea certain to spark vigorous opposition from the United States and from seed developers such as Monsanto Co.

The Commission's hesitancy stems from a need to balance U.S. trade demands against the attitudes of the European Parliament and European consumers, many of whom want mandatory labelling to decide for themselves whether to avoid the new foods, officials said.
